newsitem.title: USA: IMM currencies end mixed, stg up as yen, marks ease.
newsitem.headline: IMM currencies end mixed, stg up as yen, marks ease.

text.p: IMM currency futures finished mixed, as December sterling set a fresh contract high, while yen and Continental European contracts remained on the defensive, traders and analysts said.
December sterling established a contract high at $1.6080, breezing above the key resistance level of $1.6000, on heavy speculative and mutual fund buying, they said.
"Sterling had a nice retracement over the last few days, and was able to generate good momentum," one cash trader said. "There is still the feeling that you buy sterling on dips."
Over the last several sessions, sterling futures languished below the old contract high of $1.5996 due to profit-taking.
"Sterling is now a viable high-yielder," one trader said, referring to the decline in some European interest rates.
Mark and Swiss franc futures remained lower, with December marks erasing gains achieved on the back of Bundesbank president Hans Tietmeyer's comments.
"Tietmeyer sounded much more militant," another trader said. Tietmeyer said that he sees no need for further interest rate cuts in the foreseeable future.

December mark's rose to a weekly high of $0.6617, above the high on GLOBEX at $0.6616, or 1.5136 spot, on Tietmeyer's comments. Prior to his statements, the dollar was flirting with the 1.5250 spot, or $0.6578 in December marks.
One cash trader said buying was extremely heavy for mark/yen amid talk of a large options position at the 74.50 level.
On the floor, activity was dominated in the Mexican peso pit. One firm bought 1,000 December pesos at $0.120000, the day's low, even though the contract downticked to $0.119500.

Traders covered short positions on anticipation that Mexican officials would intervene in the currency market and prop up pesos. However, the intervention did not materialize, sending peso futures sharply lower.
"If we trade below $0.120000 for any length of time, pesos will fall hard," one floor trader said.
He estimated 9,000 contracts traded in December and 1,000 in March pesos.
Another trader said Mexican corporates were underhedged.
"They are a trifle nervous," he added.

At the end of pit trade, December yen was off $0.000046 at $0.008874, marks fell $0.0006 at $0.6595, Swiss francs were $0.0028 at $0.7970, sterling rose $0.0124 at $1.6048, Canadian dollars were up $0.0001 at $0.7457, Australian dollars were $0.0022 lower at $0.7888, and Mexican pesos were $0.000500 lower at $0.121950. -Derivatives desk 312-408-8750;E-mail derivatives@reuters.com
